member.name: T:React.DeferredDataCallback
member.summary: Callback used to retrieve event data on a deferred (delayed) basis.

remarks.para: When an 's property is set to a , the delegate will be called at the time the event is fired by the . The object returned by the delegate will then serve as the new value for the property.

The callback should always check the property before it allocates any data to the . If is true, then the data should be allocated; otherwise it should not be allocated, and any steps needed to un-reserve or deallocate data already allocated on behalf of the requesting should be taken.

member.param: The that is requesting the data.
member.returns: The event data object or if no data is available for the event.

member.name: T:React.AnonymousResource
member.summary: A that does not track its resource items as actual objects.

remarks.para: An can be created directly or via the factory method.

s are used when there is no need to track individual resource items using references to actual objects. In other words, an represents a pool of "things" that are tracked solely by the number of such things in the pool.
Items acquired from an will never provide a reference through task activation data (the data parameter of the mehtod) or the property. When an is acquired, these will always be .

member.name: T:React.Blocking`1
member.summary: Base class for most objects that can block instances.

remarks.para: is used to enforce a common idiom for all blocking objects without allowing substantially different types of blocking objects too much visibility into each other's inner-working. For example, both and are derivatives of . Because of this, each implements a common method for creating their blocking (wait) queues, getting a count of the number of blocked s on the wait queues, etc. However, neither nor directly exposes the underlying wait queues to each other. This helps ensure that dissimilar blocking objects can't intentionally or unintentionally affect each other.

Of course, by not exposing the wait queue even to sub-classes, it may make it difficult for certain functions to be carried out. As a brief aside, the class actually does expose its wait queue to sub-classes through the property, but this is not the norm for the other blocking objects.

If you absolutely, positively need access to a blocking object's wait queue (or queues), it can be easily accomplished by overriding the method and simply hanging onto the returned reference that you return to the caller. One thing to bear in mind, however, is that most of the React.NET blocking objects create their wait queue(s) on demand, so you're not immediately guaranteed access to the wait queue using these steps.

Another consideration when sub-classing is the types of wait queues the will return. This is not an issue for a blocking object that has only one wait queue, but if multiple wait queues are required, they must be of the same type. The primary reason for this restriction is that C# generics do not allow downcasting of generic types whose type parameters differ. For example, you can't create an and return it as an

member.typeparam: The type of which can be blocked.

member.summary: Gets the number of s blocking on this instance.

remarks.para: This property returns the count of all blocked s without regard for which wait queue they might actually be blocking upon. In most cases, there is only a single wait queue and therefore provides adequate insight into the number of waiting tasks. When a object has multiple wait queues, it may be necessary to query the per-queue count using the method rather than this property.
This property simply calls GetBlockCount(AllQueues).

member.value: The number of blocked s as an .

member.name: T:React.IResource
member.summary: An object that can be used as a resource in the simulation.

remarks.para: In reality, an represents a set or pool of resources that may be acquired and released by s during the course of a simulation run. Each time a resource is acquired, there is one less resource available to dispense to other s. Each time a resource is released by a , there is one more resource available to dispense. When all resources have been acquired, the next to call will be blocked until such time as another puts a resource back into the available pool by calling or .

This interface represents the minimum functionality required to act as a resource pool in a React.NET simulation. Most applications can use one of the Create methods on the class to create a resource pool.

member.name: T:React.BlockingMethodAttribute
member.summary: Attribute used to flag a method that has blocking semantics.

remarks.para: Methods that have this attribute must return a instance. This attribute is used solely to document methods that return a that must be blocked upon. The returned will perform some action on behalf of another .
This attribute can only be applied to methods.

example.para: A typical use of a blocking method from a (specifically from the method) might look something like this:

para.code: IResource resource = /* get a resource */ yield return resource.Acquire(this);

example.para: In the above case, the method is a blocking method. The it returns is blocked upon by the (by virtue of the yield return statement).

member.name: T:React.BoundedBuffer
member.summary: A concrete implementation of .

member.name: T:React.IBoundedBuffer
member.summary: An object which can serve as a bounded buffer.

remarks.para: A bounded buffer is a blocking object that has a pre-defined capacity. s that use the attempt to put items into the buffer (they are the producers) or take items from the buffer (they are the consumers).

s that are acting as producers use to attempt to add an item to the buffer. If the buffer has not yet reached its capacity the item can be added immediately; otherwise the returned by will block until such time as the buffer has room for another item.

s that are acting as consumers use to attempt to remove an item from the buffer. If the buffer is not empty an item is immediately removed; otherwise the returned by will block until such time as a producer adds an item.

member.name: T:React.Condition
member.summary: A general-purpose blocking condition that can represent true/false situations.

remarks.para: The blocks s while it is in its false, or reset state. When the becomes true, or signalled, via a call to the method, one or all blocked s are resumed.

The can be configured to automatically reset to the false state or remain true (signalled) using the property. In addition the is configurable as to whether it will resume a single waiting or all waiting s when it is signalled via .
By default when resuming single s, the s are resumed in the order they blocked on the (i.e. FIFO order).

member.name: T:React.Consumable
member.summary: A concrete implementation of .

member.name: T:React.IConsumable
member.summary: An object that can be used as a consumable in the simulation.

remarks.para: In reality, an represents a set or pool of consumables that may be acquired by s during the course of a simulation run. Each time a consumable unit is acquired, there is one less available to dispense to other s. When all consumable units have been dispensed, the next to call one of the Acquire methods will be blocked until such time as the has been re-supplied. This is the primary difference between and : instances are never released, rather at some point during the simulation it may become necessary to add units to the so that it may continue to serve requests.
This interface represents the minimum functionality required to act as a consumable pool in a React.NET simulation. Most applications can use the class rather than implementing this interface.

member.name: T:React.Simulation
member.summary: A class for running discrete-event simulations.

remarks.para: contains mechanisms for maintaining the current simulated time as well as a collection of instances scheduled to occur at some time during the simulation run. This collection is typically referred to as the the event queue, event calendar or future event set.

Fundamentally, the operation of the is quite simple. It starts with the scheduling of one or more generator instances. Internally, the generators are scheduled with s, but since it's s that perform the actual simulated processing, the generators are s rather than s.

The generator s serve to "jumpstart" or "bootstrap" the simulation. They perform some set of initialization actions, which probably result in additional activations and thus additional s being scheduled. As each is fired it runs a , and each might activate other s (or itself). Each activation places an on the event queue. This process continues until the event queue is emptied or the is ordered to stop.

Most client code will not need to call this method, rather one of the Activate methods of the class should be used to schedule s to run.
Important: If the is in the state, is silently ignored, it is not scheduled.

member.name: P:React.TaskPriority.Discardable
member.summary: Gets the discardable task priority.
member.remarks: s that are activated with the priority can be discarded by the if no higher priority tasks are pending. Put simply, if all s waiting to run have a of , then they are all thrown away by the , which will cause the to end. Discardable tasks are useful for interval-based data collection where the data collector tasks should stop when there are no more tasks of significance pending.
member.value: The discardable task priority as an . The discardable priority is defined as .

member.name: T:React.TrackedResource
member.summary: A that tracks its resource items as actual objects.

remarks.para: A can be created directly or via the factory method.
s are used when there is a need to track individual resource items using references to actual objects. In other words, a represents a pool of CLR s that are tracked by their references.

Items acquired from a will always provide a reference through task activation data (the data parameter of the mehtod) or the property. When a is acquired, these will always be reference to a live CLR .

member.name: T:React.Distribution.UniformStreams
member.summary: A set of random number generators.

remarks.para: This class is used to provide different generators to non-uniform random variates. Essentially, calls to operate as if the set was a ring buffer. Each call to returns the next in the ring buffer, starting over at the first when the last is returned.
The above behavior allows the various non-uniform random number generators used in a to draw from several generators in a well-defined manner.
Unless explicitly set, the default (system-wide) will contain random number generators.

If is one (1), then this method will always return the same .

member.name: T:React.Monitoring.TimeWeightedStatistic
member.summary: A that computes a time-weighted summary statistical value.

remarks.para: All of the time-weighted summary statistics classes in React.NET are derived from .
instance are designed to be used to monitor value changes on properties over time or to be used to compute summary statistical values on arbitrary sets of observations.

Note that is an extension of . Care must be used when calling certain of the methods that do not account for time. An example is , which, when called on a , will make all observations at the same time. This behavior may not be what is desired. Keep this fact in mind when calling methods that do not take a time parameter.
